hotels.name: Flitwick Manor
hotels.description: Flitwick Manor is a Grade II* Listed[1] Georgian country house in the south of Flitwick, Bedfordshire, England. It is located on Church Road off the A5120 road. It is currently run as a hotel by the hotelier firm Menzies.[2]

hotels.name: Luton Hoo
hotels.description: Luton Hoo is an English country house and estate between the towns of Luton, Bedfordshire and Harpenden, Hertfordshire. Most of the estate lies within the civil parish of Hyde, Bedfordshire. The unusual name "Hoo" is a Saxon word meaning the spur of a hill, and is more commonly associated with East Anglia.

hotels.name: Aldermaston Court
hotels.description: Aldermaston Park is a country house and estate built in the Victorian era with incorporations from an earlier house, located in the village of Aldermaston in the English county of Berkshire. The house was originally named Aldermaston Court, and at the turn of the 21st century was run as an wedding and corporate location known as Aldermaston Manor. The manor house and adjacent commercial buildings are currently vacant, having operated for a number of years as a hotel and office space.

hotels.name: Berystede
hotels.description: The Berystede is a hotel in South Ascot, Berkshire, England.

hotels.name: Coworth House
hotels.description: Coworth House, currently known as Coworth Park Hotel, is a late 18th-century country house situated at Sunningdale, near Ascot, in the English county of Berkshire. In 2008, its interiors were gutted and rebuilt to facilitate the house's new use as a hotel. The exterior façades were retained, but a new roof, while uniting the corps de logis and its later early 19th-century flanking wings, has marred the intended Palladian concept of the architecture.[1] Coworth House opened as a luxury hotel-spa on 27 September 2010.

hotels.name: Donnington Grove
hotels.description: Donnington Grove is a Strawberry Hill Gothic mansion, now an hotel and country club, and associated Golf Course at Donnington in the civil parish of Shaw-cum-Donnington, near Newbury, in the English county of Berkshire. It is overlooked by Donnington Castle.

hotels.name: Elcot Park Hotel
hotels.description: Coordinates: 51°25′15″N 1°25′48″W﻿ / ﻿51.4207°N 1.4301°W﻿ / 51.4207; -1.4301

hotels.name: Great House at Sonning
hotels.description: The Great House at Sonning is a hotel and restaurant with a riverside garden on the River Thames near Sonning Bridge at Sonning, Berkshire, England. It is possible for patrons to moor along the towpath running past the hotel on the river.

hotels.name: Monkey Island, Bray
hotels.description: Monkey Island is a small island in the River Thames in England, on the reach above Boveney Lock near the village of Bray, Berkshire. It is now occupied by a hotel, but sports an interesting history involving grotesquely painted monkeys and the Duke of Marlborough.

hotels.name: Oakley Court
hotels.description: Oakley Court is a Victorian Gothic country house set in 35 acres (140,000 m2) overlooking the River Thames at Water Oakley in the civil parish of Bray in the English county of Berkshire. It was built in 1859 and is currently a luxury hotel. It is a Grade II* listed building[1] has been often used as a film location.[2]

hotels.name: Royal Berkshire Hotel
hotels.description: The Royal Berkshire Hotel is a country house hotel within a noteworthy example of a late Queen Anne mansion previously called The Oaks and located at Ascot in the English county of Berkshire.[1][2]

hotels.name: Palace Hotel
hotels.description: The Palace Hotel is an historic public house situated on West Street, Old Market, Bristol. It is a grade II listed building.[1] Its exterior ornamentation includes two Assyrian-style hermai.

hotels.name: Cliveden
hotels.description: Cliveden (pronounced /ˈklɪvdən/) is an Italianate mansion and estate at Taplow, Buckinghamshire, England. Set on banks 40 metres (130 ft) above the River Thames, its grounds slope down to the river. The site has been home to an earl, three countesses, two dukes, a Prince of Wales and the Viscounts Astor.

hotels.name: The Crown
hotels.description: The Crown (also known as The Crown Inn) is a 16th-century coaching inn in Amersham, Buckinghamshire, England, located on the High Street opposite the Market Hall. The Crown is a Grade II listed building with an Elizabethan exterior and the interior retaining some original features including a mural dating to the 16th century in one bedroom. The inn is currently operated as part of an independent hotel chain, the Dhillon Group, and has interiors designed by Ilse Crawford. The hotel has 40 bedrooms, one of which was used as a location in the film Four Weddings and a Funeral. The hotel's restaurant is called The Chop House, reflecting the style of food historically served in coaching inns.

hotels.name: Danesfield House
hotels.description: Danesfield House in Medmenham, near Marlow, Buckinghamshire, England, in the Chiltern Hills is a former country house now used as a hotel and spa. The house stands on a plateau which shelves steeply down to the River Thames to the south.

hotels.name: Hartwell House
hotels.description: Hartwell House is a country house in the village of Hartwell in Buckinghamshire, southern England. The house is part of the Hartwell Estate owned by the Ernest Cook Trust, and since 2008 has been leased to The National Trust. It is a grade I listed building, and is currently used as a hotel.

hotels.name: Skindles
hotels.description: Skindles was a hotel in Maidenhead, England, on the Buckinghamshire bank of the River Thames by Maidenhead Bridge. It was formerly the Orkney Arms, built in 1743, but was turned from a coaching inn into a fashionable hotel by William Skindle in 1833.[1] In the 20th century, it became notorious as a place for adulterous assignations.[2] Its guests included Winston Churchill and Princess Margaret while musicians who performed there included The Rolling Stones and The Strawbs.[3]

hotels.name: The Bull Hotel, Cambridge
hotels.description: The Bull Hotel was a historical hotel located at 68 Trumpington Street, Cambridge, England, next to the St Catharine's College.[1]

hotels.name: The Bull Hotel, Peterborough
hotels.description: The Bull Hotel is a 17th-century AA 4-star hotel in the Westgate neighbourhood of Peterborough, Cambridgeshire, opposite the Queensgate Shopping Centre. The Bull Hotel, a Grade II listed building, is the premier hotel in Peterborough, and is the only AA recognised 4 star hotel in the city centre.[1]It has served as a notable conference location for middle England, with a capacity of 250.[2] The hotel has 118 rooms and is served by The Brasserie and the Pastroudis Bar and Cafe.

hotels.name: George Hotel, Stamford
hotels.description: The George Hotel is a former coaching inn on the route of the Great North Road in St Martin's Without, Stamford, Lincolnshire.[1][2]

hotels.name: Grange Hotel, Brampton
hotels.description: The Brampton Grange in Brampton, Cambridgeshire, England, is a historic building that dates back to 1773. The building was once vital to the planning and bombing of Germany as the United States Army Air Forces (USAAF) 1st Bombardment Division, part of the Eighth Air Force, was based here from 1943 to 1945, during the Second World War.

hotels.name: Spinney Abbey
hotels.description: Spinney Abbey, once known as Spinney Priory, is a house and farm on the site of a former monastic foundation close to the village of Wicken, on the edge of the fens in Cambridgeshire, England.

hotels.name: Toft Country House Hotel And Golf Club
Chester Grosvenor and Spa
hotels.description: The Chester Grosvenor is an hotel in Chester, England. The Grade II listed building was built between 1863 and 1866 and is owned by the Duke of Westminster. The long-standing establishment features an on-site restaurant that has been awarded a Michelin star since 1990.

hotels.name: Crewe Hall
hotels.description: Crewe Hall is a Jacobean mansion located near Crewe Green, east of Crewe, in Cheshire, England. Described by Nikolaus Pevsner as one of the two finest Jacobean houses in Cheshire,[1] it is listed at grade I. Built in 1615–36 for Sir Randolph Crewe, it was one of the county's largest houses in the 17th century, and was said to have "brought London into Cheshire".[2]

hotels.name: Crown Hotel
hotels.description: The Crown Hotel, also known as the Crown Inn, is a timber-framed, black-and-white hotel and public house located at 24–26 High Street in the town of Nantwich in Cheshire, England. The present building dates from shortly after 1583. One of three buildings in Nantwich to be listed at grade I, the listing describes the Crown Hotel as "an important late C16 building."[1]

hotels.name: Higher Huxley Hall
hotels.description: HIgher Huxley Hall is a manor house, now a luxury 5-star hotel, in Cheshire, England, located about 7 miles southeast of Chester. It lies west of the village of Huxley. Lower Huxley Hall lies less than half a mile to the immediate north of the hall. It dates from at least the 13th century and today has a white facade.[1] Once in the possession of the Cholmondeley family, in 1850 it was owned by a Mr. R. Salmon.[2] Howevever, in 1896 it was reportedly in the hands of a Mr. Vere Cholmondeley.[3]

hotels.name: Peckforton Castle
hotels.description: Peckforton Castle is a country house built in the style of a medieval castle. It stands in woodland at the north end of Peckforton Hills 1 mile (2 km) northwest of the village of Peckforton, Cheshire, England. It has been designated by English Heritage as a Grade I listed building.[1] The house was built in the middle of the 19th century as a family home for John Tollemache, a wealthy Cheshire landowner, estate manager, and Member of Parliament. It was designed by Anthony Salvin in the Gothic style. The Tollemache family continued to live in the house until 1939. During the Second World War it was used as a hostel for physically handicapped children.

hotels.name: Queen Hotel, Chester
hotels.description: Queen Hotel, Chester, is located on the corner of City Road and Station Road, Chester, Cheshire, England, and stands opposite Chester General Station. The hotel is designated by English Heritage as a Grade II listed building.[1]

hotels.name: Rookery Hall
hotels.description: Coordinates: 53°05′56″N 2°30′36″W﻿ / ﻿53.099°N 2.510°W﻿ / 53.099; -2.510

hotels.name: Rowton Hall
hotels.description: Rowton Hall Hotel is a historic stately home, now run as a hotel in Rowton, Cheshire, England. The hall was originally built in the 14th century and was rebuilt in 1779 in the Georgian style.[1][2] The Battle of Rowton Heath took place in the grounds in 1643.[2] It contains the oak-panelled Chester Restaurant.

hotels.name: Old Hall Hotel
hotels.description: The Old Hall Hotel, Sandbach, is a public house and restaurant in High Street, Sandbach. Cheshire, England. It was built in 1656 on the site of a previous manor house, and since been extended. In the 18th century it was used as a coaching inn and hotel. It closed as a hotel in 2005, it was unused for four years, and its fabric suffered serious deterioration. In 2010 the building was bought by the owners of a chain of public houses who repaired and restored it. It was reopened as a public house and restaurant in 2011. The building is timber-framed, and is designated by English Heritage as a Grade I listed building.

hotels.name: Carbis Bay Hotel
hotels.description: Carbis Bay Hotel is an AA 3-star hotel in Carbis Bay near St Ives, Cornwall.[1] It is the most prominent building in Carbis Bay, overlooking the beach.[2]

hotels.name: The Carlyon Bay Hotel, Spa & Golf Resort
Chymorvah House
hotels.description: The Chymorvah House or Chymorvah Hotel is a hotel on the eastern side of the town of Marazion in Cornwall, England, UK, several miles east of Penzance.[1] It has panoramic views of St Michael's Mount and bay and is located next to the Mount Haven Hotel which is near the coast. The granite structure was built by Richard Rooke Michell, a wealthy mine owner in the mid-19th century as a private residence. It contains 9 rooms. In 1885 it was reported to belong to a Major Field.[2]

hotels.name: Falmouth Hotel
hotels.description: The Falmouth Hotel is a hotel on the seafront in the northeastern part of Gyllyngvase in Falmouth, Cornwall. The oldest hotel in Falmouth, it opened on 9 May 1865 to provide to tourists due to the new railway station being linked nearby.[1] It is located next to the Royal Duchy Hotel. The foundation stone was laid on 6 August 1863, by Robert Tweedy and it cost about £9000.[1] Additions were added in 1880, 1898 and 1972.[2] The hotel has 71 rooms and is set in 5 acres (2.0 ha) of landscaped gardens.[3]

hotels.name: Falmouth Beach Hotel
hotels.description: Falmouth Beach Hotel is a hotel on the seafront of Gyllyngvase beach in Falmouth, Cornwall. The four storey 120 room hotel was operated by Best Western.[1][2]

hotels.name: Headland Hotel
hotels.description: The Headland Hotel is a Grade II listed building located in Newquay, Cornwall, England, United Kingdom. It was opened in June 1900 and is built in a prominent position overlooking Fistral Beach and Towan Head.

hotels.name: Jamaica Inn
hotels.description: Jamaica Inn, originally a public house and now an inn, is a Grade II listed building in the civil parish of Altarnun, Cornwall, England, United Kingdom.[1][2] Located just off the A30, near the middle of Bodmin Moor close to the hamlet of Bolventor,[2] it was built as a coaching house in 1750 as a staging post for changing horses during stagecoach runs over the moor.[1] The hill named Tuber or Two Barrows, 1,122 feet (342 m), is close-by.[3]

hotels.name: Mount Haven Hotel
hotels.description: Mount Haven Hotel is a hotel near the coast on the eastern side of the town of Marazion, Cornwall, England, UK, several miles east of Penzance.[1] It is next to Chymorvah House and has panoramic views of St Michael's Mount and bay.

hotels.name: Nansloe Manor
hotels.description: Nansloe Manor, in Helston, Cornwall, is a hotel, originally built some time in the 16th century. It has fifteen bedrooms, a restaurant, Mediterranean gardens and a wide supply of British wildlife.[citation needed]

hotels.name: The Sloop Inn
hotels.description: The Sloop Inn is an inn in St Ives, Cornwall, England, UK located on the wharf. It is one of the best known and oldest inns in Cornwall.[citation needed] The 14th century public house is dated to "circa 1312".[1]The Sloop was the favourite haunt of Louis Grier and many of his paintings hung there in earlier years.[2] The Rogers family hosted the Sloop Inn for nearly a century.

hotels.name: Tregenna Castle
hotels.description: Tregenna Castle, in St Ives, Cornwall, was built by John Stephens in the 18th century. The estate was sold in 1871 and became a hotel, a purpose for which it is still used today.

hotels.name: Abbey House, Barrow-in-Furness
hotels.description: Abbey House, Barrow-in-Furness in the modern county of Cumbria, formerly in Lancashire (England), is a Neo-Elizabethan H-plan mansion built by Sir Edwin Lutyens in 1913-14 as a guest house for Vickers Ltd and a flat for the Managing Director, Sir James McKechnie. In its abstracted, military echo of the Tudor style, it prefigures the style of Lutyens' Castle Drogo. In 1951, having been acquired by the County Council, Abbey House was made into an old people’s home, and consequently suffered considerable neglect. In 1984 it was sold by the Council and restored as an hotel. Abbey House has been a Grade II* Listed Building since 1949.[1]

hotels.name: The Bull Hotel, Sedbergh
hotels.description: The Bull Hotel, formerly The Black Bull Hotel, is a 17th-century coaching inn in Sedbergh, Cumbria. It is located in a narrow passage parallel with the Main Street of Sedbergh and contains 14 rooms.[1]Historically the inn has been used for conferences, particularly by science associations and groups such as geologists and naturalists since at least the 1880s.[2][3][4]

hotels.name: The Duke of Edinburgh Hotel
hotels.description: The Duke of Edinburgh Hotel is a 4-star luxury hotel located on Abbey Road in Barrow-in-Furness, England.[1] The building itself was built in 1871 and was granted grade II status in 1976.[2][3] The hotel was built during a period of great economic growth in Barrow, the town was home to the largest steelworks in the world and one of the most important shipyards in the country.[2] The Duke of Edinburgh Hotel soon became Barrow's most prestigious and attracted dignitaries and celebrities from across the world; some of the more notable examples being Charlie Chaplin, D. H. Lawrence and Cary Grant.[2]

hotels.name: Gilsland Spa
hotels.description: Gilsland Spa is the present-day name of a hotel at Gilsland, Cumbria, England. It is named from the sulphurous spring which issues from a cliff below the hotel.

hotels.name: Hipping Hall
hotels.description: Hipping Hall is a country house hotel on the border of Lancashire, Cumbria and North Yorkshire, near Kirkby Lonsdale.

hotels.name: Howtown Hotel
hotels.description: Howtown Hotel is a hotel in Howtown, Cumbria, England, located near the southern shore of the Ullswater lake.[1] Although it won the César Award for Best Hotel in 1991 by The Good Hotel Guide,[2] Lonely Planet describes the hotel as "bewitchingly backwards" with early 20th century decor.[3] As of 2001, the hotel contained 10 double rooms, 2 single rooms and 4 self-catering cottages. It has been run by four generations of the Baldry family since it opened in 1903.

hotels.name: Moresby Hall
hotels.description: Moresby Hall is a former manor house and hotel in Parton, Cumbria, overlooking the Cumbrian Fells.

hotels.name: Rowanfield
hotels.description: Rowanfield is a neighbourhood in Cheltenham, England. It consists primarily of a social housing estate of Wimpey no-fines houses and low-rise flats, built around 1953, with Rowanfield School and a playing field to the West separating it from Hesters Way and also the older Rowanfield Road to the East. To the south-west Rowanfield borders the district of St Mark's. Rowanfield is located 1.5 miles west of the centre of Cheltenham.

hotels.name: Sharrow Bay
hotels.description: Coordinates: 54°35′24″N 2°50′38″W﻿ / ﻿54.590°N 2.844°W﻿ / 54.590; -2.844

hotels.name: Storrs Hall
hotels.description: Storrs Hall is a four-star hotel on the banks of Windermere in the Lake District, Cumbria, England. The hotel, a Grade II* listed Georgian mansion, is also home to the National Trust-owned folly the "Temple" on the end of a stone jetty on Windermere.

hotels.name: Windermere Hotel
hotels.description: Windermere Hotel , originally The Riggs Windermere,[1] is a hotel in Windermere, Cumbria, England, located near Windermere railway station.[2] The hotel opened at the time that the railway link with Kendal was established in 1847.[3][4] It overlooks the A591 road.

hotels.name: Breadsall Priory
hotels.description: Breadsall Priory is a former Augustinian priory in Derbyshire, about a mile to the north of Breadsall, and about a mile to the east of Little Eaton. It was established by a member of the Curzon family before 1266, and was only a very small priory, and was dissolved in 1536.

hotels.name: Old Hall Hotel
hotels.description: The Old Hall Hotel is a hotel in Buxton, Derbyshire, England, and is one of the oldest buildings in the town.[1] The current building dates from the Restoration period, built around and incorporating an earlier fortified tower.

hotels.name: Santo's Higham Farm
hotels.description: Santo's Higham Farm Hotel is a hotel based in the Derbyshire countryside, overlooking the Amber Valley. The hotel has 28 en-suite bedrooms and a restaurant with à la carte and table d'hôte cuisine. Santo's Higham Farm has been awarded an AA rosette,[1] an EnjoyEngland silver award [2] and a Visit Britain 3* award.[3]

hotels.name: St Helen's House
hotels.description: St Helen's House is a Grade I listed building situated in King Street, Derby, England. Now leased as offices, it has been used in the past as a private residence and as an educational establishment.

hotels.name: The Barn, Exmouth
hotels.description: The Barn, in Exmouth, Devon, England, is a seaside house, now a hotel, dating from 1896 and designed in Arts and Crafts style by the architect Edward Schroeder Prior. It is a Grade II* listed building.[1]

hotels.name: Burgh Island Hotel
hotels.description: The Burgh Island Hotel is a hotel on Burgh Island, Devon in England.

hotels.name: Churston Court Inn
hotels.description: Churston Court Inn is a historical 12th century coaching inn in Churston near Brixham, Devon. A Grade II* listed building, it is located next to the old church and farm and retains its original staircases, stone windows, and oak panelling and flagstone floors. The inn has 20 (19 now according to the official site) en-suite rooms with four poster beds. The inn is said to be haunted by the ghost of a monk in the old kitchen. [1][2]

hotels.name: Corbyn Head Hotel
hotels.description: Corbyn Head Hotel is an AA three star rosette hotel on the seafront of Torbay Road, Torbay, Devon.[1] The hotel had 52 bedrooms in 1990 but currently has 45 bedrooms.[2] It is often used for conferences in Torbay.[3]

hotels.name: The Fisherman's Cot
hotels.description: The Fisherman's Cot is an inn on the A3072 road to the northwest of Bickleigh near Tiverton, in northeastern Devon. It is operated by Marston's Inns and lies on the River Exe.[1]

hotels.name: Gleneagles Hotel, Torquay
hotels.description: The Gleneagles Hotel is a hotel in Torquay, Devon, England. It is best known as the inspiration for the British situation comedy Fawlty Towers.[1] It was owned by Donald Sinclair until 1973.[2] The hotel contains 41 rooms and is owned by Best Western.

hotels.name: Grand Hotel (Torquay)
hotels.description: The Grand Hotel is a hotel in Torquay, Devon. The grand white hotel is closely associated with Agatha Christie, who spent her honeymoon here.[1]The Grand Hotel has 132 bedrooms and 4 floors.

hotels.name: Royal Castle Hotel
hotels.description: The Royal Castle Hotel is an AA three-star hotel in Dartmouth, Devon. It is situated with a view of Dartmouth Harbour and the River Dart estuary.[1] In the past, the hotel located on Dartmouth's waterfront had the distinction of hosting Queen Victoria, Sir Francis Drake, and Mary (who later became Mary II of England). The hotel was used as a location for the 1984 film, "Ordeal by Innocence", which was based on the 1958 Agatha Christie novel of the same name and starred Donald Sutherland, Faye Dunaway, Christopher Plummer and Sarah Miles. Agatha Christie renamed the hotel the Royal George in 'The Regatta Mystery', a short story that first appeared in The Strand Magazine in 1936 and which currently forms part of the 1991 short story collection Problem at Pollensa Bay.

hotels.name: The Three Crowns Hotel
hotels.description: The Three Crowns Hotel, also Three Crowns Chagford, is a historical hotel in Chagford, Devon, England. The building dates to the 13th century and was several centuries was a manor house before becoming an inn. The hotel, noted for its 13th century granite facade, has 16 en suite rooms.[1] The hotel has been reported to be haunted since 1643 by Sidney Godolphin, a poet who fought as a Cavalier during the English Civil War and is said to stride the corridors in full uniform.[2] It is a Grade II* listed building [3]

hotels.name: Bournemouth Highcliff Marriott Hotel
hotels.description: Coordinates: 50°42′58″N 1°52′59″W﻿ / ﻿50.716°N 1.883°W﻿ / 50.716; -1.883

hotels.name: Crown Hotel, Poole
hotels.description: The Crown Hotel is a hotel in Poole, Dorset, England. It is a traditional pub/inn with a cream painted exterior and red placard. It is reputedly haunted, with ghosts of children and of deformed twins of the 17th century who were kept locked up in a room upstairs.[1] The hotel piano is often said to play notes seemingly on its own accord.[2] A girl in a white nightdress has often been reported leaning over the banister.[3]

hotels.name: Haven Hotel
hotels.description: The Haven Hotel is an AA four star hotel in Sandbanks, near Poole, Dorset on the south coast of England.

hotels.name: Royal Lion Hotel
hotels.description: The Royal Lion Hotel is a hotel in Lyme Regis, Dorset, England. It lies to the northwest of the Lyme Regis Museum, about 100 metres from the sea. It is a former coaching inn, dated to 1610 (although the official site claims 1601).[1] It is reputedly haunted; many unexplained ectoplasms have been sighted in the corridors and cold spots.[2]

hotels.name: Sandbanks Hotel
hotels.description: Coordinates: 50°41′38″N 1°55′52″W﻿ / ﻿50.694°N 1.931°W﻿ / 50.694; -1.931

hotels.name: Blackwell Grange Hotel
hotels.description: Coordinates: 54°30′50″N 1°34′05″W﻿ / ﻿54.514°N 1.568°W﻿ / 54.514; -1.568

hotels.name: The Lord Crewe Arms Hotel
hotels.description: The Lord Crewe Arms Hotel is a medieval hotel in Blanchland, Northumberland, England. It is dated to 1165 and was used as a hiding hole by monks of nearby Blanchland Abbey for centuries and has hidden stairways and stone flagged floors. The hotel is built upon the former abbey guest house and the windows reflect this monastic past while the battlemented tower has a martial theme.

hotels.name: Lumley Castle
hotels.description: Lumley Castle is a 14th-century quadrangular castle at Chester-le-Street in the North of England, near to the city of Durham and a property of the Earl of Scarbrough. It is a Grade I listed building.[1]

hotels.name: Seaham Hall
hotels.description: Coordinates: 54°50′53″N 1°20′42″W﻿ / ﻿54.848°N 1.345°W﻿ / 54.848; -1.345

hotels.name: East Sussex National Golf Hotel and Spa
Grand Hotel Eastbourne
hotels.description: The Grand Hotel is a Victorian hotel also known as the 'White Palace' is located on King Edwards Parade, Eastbourne in East Sussex England. This 5 star hotel is part of an independent UK based hotel group, Elite Hotels who also own Tylney Hall in Hampshire, Ashdown Park Hotel near Forest Row and Luton Hoo in Luton.

hotels.name: The Mermaid Inn
hotels.description: The Mermaid Inn is a Grade II* listed historical inn located on Mermaid Street in the ancient town of Rye, East Sussex, southeastern England.[1] One of the best-known inns in southeast England, it was established in the 12th century and has a long, turbulent history. The current building dates from 1420 and has 16th-century additions in the Tudor style, but cellars built in 1156 survive.[2] The inn has a strong connection with the notorious Hawkhurst Gang of smugglers, who used it in the 1730s and 1740s as one of their strongholds: Rye was a thriving port during this period. Some of the smugglers, their mistresses and other characters are reported to haunt the inn.

hotels.name: Five Lakes Hotel, Golf, Country Club & Spa
Speech House
hotels.description: Coordinates: 51°48′24″N 2°33′09″W﻿ / ﻿51.80655°N 2.55243°W﻿ / 51.80655; -2.55243

hotels.name: Stonehouse Court Hotel
hotels.description: Coordinates: 51°44′38″N 2°17′35″W﻿ / ﻿51.744°N 2.293°W﻿ / 51.744; -2.293 The Stonehouse Court is a Grade II listed manor house in Stonehouse, Gloucestershire, England which is now a hotel. It is located next to St Cyr's Church and the Stroudwater Canal.

hotels.name: Thornbury Castle
hotels.description: Coordinates: 51°36′49″N 2°31′48″W﻿ / ﻿51.6136°N 2.5301°W﻿ / 51.6136; -2.5301

hotels.name: Tortworth Court
hotels.description: Tortworth Court is a Victorian mansion in South Gloucestershire built in Tudor style for the 2nd Earl of Ducie[1] between 1848 and 1853. Its architect was Samuel Sanders Teulon. The house is situated in the civil parish of Tortworth, near Thornbury in South Gloucestershire, England.

hotels.name: Beaumont College
hotels.description: Beaumont College was a Jesuit public school in Old Windsor, Berkshire, England. In 1967 the school closed. The property became a conference centre, and from 2008 a hotel. St John's Beaumont, the preparatory school for boys aged 3-13, is still in operation.

hotels.name: 41 Hotel
hotels.description: 41 Hotel or No. 41: A Red Carnation Hotel is a luxury hotel in London, England. It is located just south of Buckingham Palace along 41 Buckingham Palace Road.

hotels.name: The Academy (Hotel)
hotels.description: The Academy is a 4 star London hotel with 49 rooms, located in the Garden Square district of Bloomsbury. The hotel, which opened in March 2000, was originally five private homes built in 1776. The hotel is managed by The Eton Collection. The hotel is paired with the British Museum and offers packages with exclusive access to curators and exhibition talks.[1]

hotels.name: The Athenaeum Hotel
hotels.description: The Athenaeum is a family-owned five-star hotel overlooking Green Park in Piccadilly, London.

hotels.name: Baglioni Hotel
hotels.description: Baglioni Hotel London by Baglioni Hotels is a luxury 5-star hotel in London, England. It is located at Hyde Park Gate in the Kensington area of London in a Georgian era building overlooking Hyde Park. It is owned by Baglioni, an Italian hotel firm which also has branches in Venice, Milan and several other places.

hotels.name: Bell Savage Inn
hotels.description: The Bell Savage Inn was a former public house in London, England, from the 15th century to 1873, originally located on the north side of what is now Ludgate Hill, in the City of London. It was a playhouse during the Elizabethan Era, as well as a venue for various other entertainments. It was also an important coaching inn. Other names by which it has been known throughout history include: Savage's Inn, The Bel Savage, Belle Savage, Belle Sauvage, Bell on the Hoop, Old Bell Savage, Belly Savage and others.

hotels.name: The Bentley London
hotels.description: Coordinates: 51°29′34″N 0°11′03″W﻿ / ﻿51.4928°N 0.1842°W﻿ / 51.4928; -0.1842

hotels.name: The Berkeley
hotels.description: The Berkeley is a five star deluxe hotel, located in Wilton Place, Knightsbridge, London. It is managed by Maybourne Hotel Group, who also manage Claridge's and The Connaught in Mayfair, London.

hotels.name: Blakes Hotel
hotels.description: Blakes Hotel is a 5-star hotel in London, credited as being one of the firstboutique hotels in the world.[1] It is located at 33 Roland Gardens in South Kensington. The hotel was established in 1978 by Anouska Hempel, the London hotelier and designer,[2] and contains eclectic artefacts from all over the world - collected by Hempel during her travels from China to Cambodia.[3] Known for protecting the privacy of its clients from the paparazzi, it's the London base of film stars, musicians and top designers earning the reputation as the "couture hotel". Regular guests have included Princess Margaret, Sarah Ferguson the Duchess of York, actress Gywyneth Paltrow, Lindsay Lohan and supermodel Kate Moss.

hotels.name: Brown's Hotel
hotels.description: Brown's Hotel is a luxury 5-star hotel in London, United Kingdom. Opened in 1837, it is one of London's most established hotels, celebrating its 175th anniversary in 2012.[1] Brown's has been owned by The Rocco Forte Collection since 3 July 2003 and is a member of The Leading Hotels of the World.

hotels.name: Cadogan Hotel
hotels.description: The Cadogan Hotel /kəˈdɒɡən/[citation needed] is a hotel located in Sloane Street, Knightsbridge, London, England that was built in 1887.

hotels.name: Capital Hotel
hotels.description: Capital Hotel is a small 5-star hotel in London, England. It is located at 22-24 Basil Street, Knightsbridge, and is known to have been visited by The Queen.[1]

hotels.name: Carlton Hotel, London
hotels.description: The Carlton Hotel was a luxury hotel that operated from 1899 to 1940. It was designed by the architect C. J. Phipps as part of a larger development that included the rebuilding of Her Majesty's Theatre, which is adjacent to the hotel site. The Carlton was originally run by the Swiss hotelier César Ritz, with Auguste Escoffier as the head chef. In its early days it was one of London's most fashionable hotels and drew some custom away from the Savoy Hotel, which Ritz and Escoffier had previously managed.

hotels.name: Charlotte Street Hotel
hotels.description: Charlotte Street Hotel is a luxury 5-star hotel in London, England. It is located at 15 Charlotte Street in North Soho.[1] The hotel opened on June 5, 2000 and contains 52 rooms.[2]

hotels.name: Churchill Hotel
hotels.description: The 'Hyatt Regency London – The Churchill is a five star hotel located on Portman Square, north of Marble Arch in central London, England. It is owned by The Churchill Group Ltd and is currently operated by Hyatt Hotels Corporation.

hotels.name: Claridge's
hotels.description: Claridge's is a 5-star hotel at the corner of Brook Street and Davies Street in Mayfair, London. It has long-standing connections with royalty that have led to it sometimes being referred to as an "annexe to Buckingham Palace".

hotels.name: Colonnade Hotel, London
hotels.description: The Colonnade Hotel (previously known as The Esplanade hotel) is a 4-star London hotel with 43 rooms, of which 3 are suites. The hotel is located opposite Warwick Avenue tube station and Little Venice.

hotels.name: The Connaught (hotel)
hotels.description: The Connaught in Carlos Place, Mayfair, central London, is a five star hotel.

hotels.name: Courthouse Hotel
hotels.description: Courthouse Hotel, formerly the Courthouse Kempinski, and prior to the hotel, Great Marlborough Street Magistrates Court is a 5-star hotel in London, England at 19-21 Great Marlborough Street, in Soho.

hotels.name: Covent Garden Hotel
hotels.description: Covent Garden Hotel is a 5-star hotel in London, England.[1] It is located near Seven Dials in the West End, a short walk away from the Royal Opera House, and is surrounded by some 21 theatres. The hotel is part of Tim and Kit Kemp's Firmdale Hotels.[2]

hotels.name: Draycott Hotel
hotels.description: Draycott Hotel is a 5-star hotel in London, England.

hotels.name: Driscoll House
hotels.description: Driscoll House is a building at 172 New Kent Road, London, England, which has operated as a hostel since 1913. The building is on the south side of New Kent Road, between the Bricklayers' Arms flyover and Elephant and Castle station, and is a well-detailed example of the pre-World War I institutional Baroque style.

hotels.name: Durrants
hotels.description: Durrants is a hotel located in London on George Street.

hotels.name: Egerton House Hotel
hotels.description: Egerton House Hotel is an AA five star double-townhouse hotel located at 17-19 Egerton Terrace off Brompton Road in the Knightsbridge area of London.[1] It is part of the Red Carnation Hotels group. The hotel consists of two adjoining Victorian townhouses constructed from red-brick, which were originally built in 1843. It is managed by Michelle Devlin and Annie McCrann.[2] The hotel has 28 en-suite rooms and a number of suites. The hotel is consistently rated within the top 10 best reviewed hotels within London on Tripadvisor.com

hotels.name: Four Seasons Canary Wharf
hotels.description: Four Seasons Hotel London at Canary Wharf is a luxury 5-star hotel in London, England. It is located at 46 Westferry Circus in Canary Wharf. The hotel has 142 rooms and suites containing large bay windows overlooking the River Thames. Its Ancient Egyptian inspired design by Renton, Howard, Wood & Levin, based on earlier work by Philippe Starck,[1] features a curved patinated copper roof.[2] This bold architecture was seen as a departure from the previous conservatism of the Four Seasons group.[3]

hotels.name: Four Seasons London
hotels.description: Four Seasons Hotel London at Park Lane is a luxury 5-star hotel in London, England. It is located near Hyde Park corner in central London. It was built in 1970 as the Inn on the Park London.

hotels.name: Franklin Hotel, London
hotels.description: Franklin Hotel is a luxury 5-star hotel in London, England. It is located at 22-28 Egerton Gardens, Knightsbridge on the borders of Chelsea.

hotels.name: Goring Hotel
hotels.description: The Goring Hotel /ˈɡɔərɪŋ/ is a luxury 5-star hotel in London, England. It is located near Buckingham Palace.

hotels.name: Grange City Hotel
hotels.description: Grange City Hotel is a luxury 5-star hotel in London, England. It is located at 8–14 Cooper's Row near the Tower of London. The hotel encompasses 12 floors and has 307 en-suite rooms, 10 suites, 1 penthouse and 15 conference and syndicate rooms.

hotels.name: Grange Holborn Hotel
hotels.description: Grange Holborn Hotel is a luxury five-star hotel in London, England. It is located at fifty-sixty Southampton Row in the West End.

hotels.name: Grosvenor House Hotel
hotels.description: Coordinates: 51°30′35.2″N 0°9′19.7″W﻿ / ﻿51.509778°N 0.155472°W﻿ / 51.509778; -0.155472

hotels.name: Halkin Hotel
hotels.description: The Halkin (styled as The Halkin by COMO) is a luxury boutique 5-star hotel in London, England. It is located in Belgravia, one of London's most affluent districts, just to the east of Belgrave Square near Grosvenor Crescent. It is operated by the COMO Hotels and Resorts Group, and has the distinction of being their first property.[1] It is also considered to be one of the first boutique hotels in London.[2] The Halkin has a Georgian-styled façade of bricks and stone, but its interior and its 41 rooms and suites uses a warm contemporary design. The interior was designed by Italian designer Edith Leschke.[3]

hotels.name: Hazlitt's
hotels.description: Hazlitt's is a townhouse hotel located at 6 Frith Street, Soho Square, London, in very close proximity to Soho Theatre. The building is Georgian and dates back to 1718,[1] four storeys, with typical long Georgian-bay windows painted stylishly in beige. Owned by Peter McKay, it is named after the essayist William Hazlitt who died in the house in 1830; he has a blue plaque on the wall to the left of the front door.[2]The hotel was awarded the César Award for London Hotel of the Year by The Good Hotel Guide in 2002.[2]In 2002 it reportedly had 19 double rooms, 3 single rooms, 1 suite, 23 in total, [3]and 3 rooms on the ground floor.[2]The rooms are furnished with four poster beds, antiques and old paintings and the bathrooms contain claw-footed baths.[4]The hotel is said to contain over 2000 paintings or prints.[5]The hotel, due to its heritage, is popular with writers,[4] but also artists, actors and models.[5][6]The rooftop of the hotel has been used for photoshoots.[7]

hotels.name: Hempel Hotel
hotels.description:
The Hempel Hotel was a luxury 5-star hotel in London, England. It was located at 31-35 Craven Hill Gardens to the north of Hyde Park off Bayswater Road. It was a small boutique hotel with Zen inspiration, designed by noted designer Anouska Hempel.[1] The design of each of the 40 rooms and 10 apartments centered around minimalistic art and the color white. It also featured a "Zen Garden". The hotel was a favourite of Victoria Beckham and of Michael Jackson, who reserved the entire hotel during a stay there in 2006.[2] It was noted as a minimalist hotel.[3]
The hotel has been sold in January 2013 and is now, until further notice, closed.

hotels.name: Hilton London Metropole
hotels.description: The Hilton London Metropole Hotel is a 4-star hotel and conference centre located on the Edgware Road in central London. It is bounded by the Marylebone Flyover to the north, Praed Street to the south, and the Paddington Basin development to the west. The hotel has 1054 bedrooms.

hotels.name: Hilton London Paddington
hotels.description: The Hilton London Paddington, formerly the Great Western Royal Hotel, is a hotel that forms part of the Paddington Station complex in London, England. The hotel was originally the idea of Isambard Kingdom Brunel, who was the hotel's first managing director. The funding came in large part from the Directors of the Great Western Railway Company, who were persuaded by Brunel to buy shares in the project. The hotel was built on Praed Street in the early 1850s and opened on 9th of June 1854 by H.R.H. The Prince Albert, Prince Consort, having taken 14 months to build. The hotel was designed by architect Philip Charles Hardwick, costing approximately £60,000 including all furnishing and fittings - a building which was 'to rival the facilities of the great hotels on the Continent'. The building effectively forms the main façade of the station, closing off the end of the train shed at the head of the terminal platforms. It was built by Messrs Holland Hannen & Cubitts, the building firm founded by Thomas Cubitt.[1]

hotels.name: Hotel Cecil
hotels.description: The Hotel Cecil was a grand hotel built 1890–96 between the Thames Embankment and the Strand in London, EnglandCoordinates: 51°30′36″N 0°07′18″W﻿ / ﻿51.51008°N 0.12176°W﻿ / 51.51008; -0.12176. It was named after Cecil House (also known as Salisbury House), a mansion belonging to the Cecil family, which occupied the site in the 17th century.

hotels.name: Hotel Russell
hotels.description: The Hotel Russell [1] is a four star hotel, located on Russell Square, Bloomsbury, London, owned and operated by the Principal Hayley Group. It was built in 1898 by the architect, Charles Fitzroy Doll. It is distinctively clad in decorative thé-au-lait ("tea with milk") terracotta, and was based on the Château de Madrid on the Bois de Boulogne in Paris. Its restaurant, which is named after the architect, is said to be almost identical to the RMS Titanic's dining room which he also designed.

hotels.name: InterContinental London
hotels.description: InterContinental London Park Lane is a luxury 5-star hotel in London, England. It is located at 1 Hamilton Place on Hyde Park Corner with Park Lane, close to the shopping centre of Knightsbridge and Picadilly.The hotel is operated by the InterContinental Hotels Group as part of the InterContinental chain, and was built in 1974.

hotels.name: Jumeirah Carlton Tower
hotels.description: Carlton Tower Hotel or Jumeirah Carlton Tower is a luxury 5-star hotel in London, England. Owned and managed by the Emirati firm Jumeirah who have most of their hotels in Dubai, it is located on Cadogan Place next to Sloane Street and is extremely close to Harrods, Harvey Nichols and the centre of Knightsbridge. Prior to Jumeirah, the hotel was managed by Hyatt as the Park Hyatt Carlton Tower. The hotel was voted ‘Best UK Business Hotel’ at the Conde Nast Reader’s Travel Awards in 2008 as well as Conde Nast Middle East Readers’ Choice Awards 2013 - Best International Business Hotel amongst various TripAdvisor and World Travel Awards.[1] The hotel is home to three restaurants and bars which include The Rib Room Bar & Restaurant, known for its roast rib of beef with Yorkshire pudding and the Dover sole. Other dining outlets at Jumeirah Carlton Tower include Chinoiserie, an all-day dining outlet located just off the lobby of the hotel.

hotels.name: Knightsbridge Green Hotel
hotels.description: Knightsbridge Green Hotel is a hotel in London which includes 28 rooms.[1] The hotel is housed in an 1890s structure which was converted to a hotel in 1966.[2][3] It is located near Harrods.[3]

hotels.name: The Landmark London
hotels.description: The Landmark London is a five-star hotel on Marylebone Road on the northern side of central London, England in the borough of London named the City of Westminster. It was originally opened by the Great Central Railway, under the title Hotel Great Central.

hotels.name: The Lanesborough
hotels.description: Coordinates: 51°30′9″N 0°9′10″W﻿ / ﻿51.50250°N 0.15278°W﻿ / 51.50250; -0.15278

hotels.name: Langham Hotel, London
hotels.description: The Langham, London is one of the largest and best known traditional style grand hotels in London. It is in the district of Marylebone on Langham Place and faces up Portland Place towards Regent's Park. It is a member of the Leading Hotels of the World marketing consortium.

hotels.name: London Hilton on Park Lane
hotels.description: Coordinates: 51°30′20.16″N 0°9′1.07″W﻿ / ﻿51.5056000°N 0.1502972°W﻿ / 51.5056000; -0.1502972

hotels.name: Mandarin Oriental Hyde Park, London
hotels.description: Mandarin Oriental Hyde Park, London is a five-star hotel, located in the Knightsbridge district of London, owned and managed by Mandarin Oriental Hotel Group. Housed in an historic, Edwardian-style building, the hotel originally opened its doors to the public as the Hyde Park Hotel in 1902. Mandarin Oriental Hotel Group purchased the hotel in 1996 and conducted a complete renovation of the 198 rooms and suites, as well as a re-design of the restaurants and bar. Mandarin Oriental Hyde Park, London re-opened in May 2000.[1][2]

hotels.name: Marriott London Park Lane
hotels.description: Marriott London Park Lane Hotel is a luxury 5-star hotel in London, England. It is located at 140 Park Lane and is run by the Marriott Hotels group. The site was once occupied by Somerset House and Camelford House.

hotels.name: Marriott West India Quay
hotels.description: The London Marriott Hotel, West India Quay is a luxury 5-star hotel in London, England. It is located at 22 Hertsmere Road, Canary Wharf overlooking the West India Quay Marina. It is operated by the Marriott Hotels group and has 301 rooms.

hotels.name: Le Meridien Hotel Piccadilly
hotels.description: Le Méridien Piccadilly is a luxury 5-star hotel in London, England. The rooms are divided into sets by type including Classic Rooms, Deluxe Rooms, Club Rooms and Executive Junior Suites.

hotels.name: Metropole Hotel, London
hotels.description: The Corinthia Hotel London at the corner of Northumberland Avenue and Whitehall Place in London, is a historic luxury hotel and former British Government building, located on a triangular site between Trafalgar Square and the Thames Embankment.

hotels.name: Millennium Bailey's Hotel
hotels.description: Millennium Bailey's Hotel, formerly Bailey's Hotel, is a historic hotel in the Kensington district of London. The postal address is 140 Gloucester Road, but the main entrance is on Courtfield Road, opposite Gloucester Road tube station. It was established in 1876 and named after its original owner, Sir James Bailey (1840-1910), Member of Parliament.[1]

hotels.name: Millennium Hotel Mayfair
hotels.description: Millennium Hotel Mayfair is a luxury 4-star hotel in London, England. It is located at 44 Grosvenor Square, Mayfair to the east of Hyde Park and northeast of the Knightsbridge centre. The deluxe rooms to the hotels are a minimum 36 sq metres in size and are decorated in traditional furnishings.

hotels.name: One Aldwych
hotels.description: One Aldwych is a hotel in London, England, founded by Gordon Campbell Gray. One Aldwych lies in the Aldwych in Covent Garden in City of Westminster.

hotels.name: Orchard Court
hotels.description: Orchard Court is an apartment block situated on the eastern side of Portman Square in London. Apartment number six was used by F section of the Special Operations Executive as an office for briefing agents during the Second World War.

hotels.name: Park Lane Hotel
hotels.description: The Park Lane Hotel is a 5 Star hotel on Piccadilly, London.

hotels.name: Park Lane Mews Hotel
hotels.description: The Park Lane Mews Hotel (formerly the Hilton London Mews Hotel) is a luxury 4-star boutique hotel in London's Mayfair district.

hotels.name: Radisson Edwardian Hampshire Hotel
hotels.description: Radisson Blu Edwardian Hampshire Hotel is a luxury 5-star hotel in London, England. It is located on Leicester Square in Mayfair. The hotel has 127 rooms and 20 suites.[1] Construction of the building began in 1873 and finished in 1882.

hotels.name: Radisson Edwardian Heathrow Hotel
hotels.description: Radisson Blu Edwardian Heathrow Hotel is a luxury hotel in west London, England. It is located at 140 Bath Road in Hayes, London Borough of Hillingdon, in close proximity to Heathrow Airport. The hotel is operated by the Radisson Hotels group and owned by Indian entrepreneur Jasminder Singh.[1]

hotels.name: Rafayel on the Left Bank
hotels.description: Rafayel on the Left Bank is a luxury eco hotel located at Falcon Wharf, Battersea in the London Borough of Wandsworth. The Falcon Wharf complex was originally developed by George Wimpey Ltd and was designed by architect James Burland of Burland TM. The 17 storey building is composed of four blue-clad curved towers and is situated by the River Thames, close to the London Heliport; it is one of the tallest riverside residential buildings in Battersea.[1] At the 2006 What? House Awards, the Falcon Wharf complex was awarded the “Bronze” prize in the “Best Apartment Category”.[2] In 2007 Falcon Wharf was joint winner at the British Home Awards in the category of “Apartment Building of the Year – 2007”.[3]

hotels.name: Renaissance Chancery Court Hotel
hotels.description: Rosewood London Hotel, formerly Chancery Court, is a luxury 5-star hotel in London, England. It is located at 252 High Holborn in the Holborn neighbourhood of the West End. It is located in a 1914 neoclassical building designed by H Percy Monckton which was formerly the headquarters of the Pearl Assurance Company from 1914 to 1989. The principal façades, as well as the interiors of the former East (now Scarfes Bar at Rosewood London) and West Banking Halls (now Holborn Dining Room) and the Grand Staircase are all protected with Listed Building status.

hotels.name: Ritz Hotel
hotels.description: The Ritz London is a 5-star hotel located in Piccadilly in London, England.

hotels.name: Royal Garden Hotel
hotels.description: Royal Garden Hotel is a 5 red star hotel in London, England. It is located in the heart of Kensington, on Kensington High Street, overlooking Kensington Palace and gardens. The palace, Hyde Park and the Royal Albert Hall can all be seen from the hotel.

hotels.name: Royal Horseguards Hotel
hotels.description: The Royal Horseguards Hotel is a 5-star[1] London hotel situated in the area of Whitehall. It is operated by Guoman Hotels, a subsidiary of Thistle Hotels.

hotels.name: Samarkand Hotel
hotels.description: Lansdowne Crescent is a crescent in Notting Hill, Holland Park, London W11, England.[1] It lies west off Ladbroke Grove (designated the B450).

hotels.name: San Domenico House
hotels.description: San Domenico House, a 5-star hotel in London, England. It is a small boutique hotel, located just off Kings Road at 29-31 Draycott Place in Chelsea. It has traditional and neo-classical furnishings. Formerly known as the Sloane Hotel until 2006 when it was situated at number 29.[1] Expanded after 2006 into the adjacent property with 15 extra rooms.[2]

hotels.name: Sanderson Hotel
hotels.description: The Sanderson Hotel was constructed on Berners Street, London during 1958 as the new headquarters and showroom for Arthur Sanderson and Sons, manufacturers of wallpaper, fabrics and paint for its centennial. It was designed by architect Jeff Holroyd, of the architectural firm, Slater and Uren. The original design allowed for dynamic room configurations. The building plan was fabricated around an open-to-the-sky inner courtyard with a Japanese garden designed by Philip Hicks. In 1991, the Sanderson building was listed Grade II* by the government’s English Heritage Commission. It was reopened on April 25, 2000 by Morgans Hotel Group after refurbishment by Philippe Starck and Denton Corker Marshall.

hotels.name: Savoy Hotel
hotels.description: The Savoy Hotel is a luxury hotel located on the Strand in the City of Westminster in central London. Built by impresario Richard D'Oyly Carte with profits from his Gilbert and Sullivan operas, it opened on 6 August 1889. It was the first in the Savoy group of hotels and restaurants owned by Carte's family for over a century. The Savoy was the first luxury hotel in Britain, introducing electric lights throughout the building, electric lifts, bathrooms in most of the lavishly furnished rooms, constant hot and cold running water, and many other innovations. Carte hired manager César Ritz and French chef Auguste Escoffier, who established an unprecedented standard of quality in hotel service, entertainment and elegant dining, attracting royalty and other wealthy guests and diners. Winston Churchill frequently took his cabinet to lunch at the hotel.[1]

hotels.name: Selsdon Park Hotel
hotels.description: Selsdon Park Hotel, a luxury hotel located in Selsdon, London, England. It is housed in a country house which was for much of the 19th century the seat of the Bishops of Rochester, although the building has since that time been greatly expanded.

hotels.name: Sheraton Park Tower Hotel
hotels.description: The Park Tower Knightsbridge Hotel is a luxury 5-star hotel in London, England. It is situated at 101 Knightsbridge near Hyde Park, in the Belgravian district of The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea. Its restaurant One-O-One headed by chef Pascal Proyart has been voted "Best Fish Restaurant" by Harden's Guide for five consecutive years.[1]

hotels.name: Sheraton Skyline Hotel at London Heathrow
hotels.description: Sheraton Skyline Hotel at London Heathrow is a luxury 5-star hotel in London, England. It is located at Bath Road in Hayes Middlesex, in close proximity to Heathrow Airport. The hotel is operated by the Sheraton hotel group and has 350 rooms.

hotels.name: Sofitel St. James
hotels.description: Sofitel St. James is a luxury 5-star hotel in London, England. It located at 6 Waterloo Place on the corner with Pall Mall in the City of Westminster, and is located near St. James's Park and Buckingham Palace.

hotels.name: Soho Hotel
hotels.description: Soho Hotel is a luxury 5-star hotel in London, England. It is located at 4 Richmond Mews in Soho. Operated by the Firmdale Hotels London group, the hotel has 91 rooms.

hotels.name: St James's Club and Hotel
hotels.description: The St James's Hotel and Club is an internationally famous and luxurious five star hotel[1] at 7-8, Park Place, St. James's, London SW1A 1LP. The hotel is part of the Lahore based Nishat Group which is owned by Pakistani billionaire Mian Mohammad Mansha.[2] The hotel has fifty-six rooms and twelve suites, many of which have their own terraces, plus a penthouse with a party deck for sixty people.[3]

hotels.name: St. Pancras Renaissance London Hotel
hotels.description: The St. Pancras Renaissance London Hotel is a hotel in the English city of London, forming the frontispiece of St Pancras railway station. It opened in 2011, but occupies much of the former Midland Grand Hotel designed by George Gilbert Scott which opened in 1873 and closed in 1935. Between 1935 and 2011, the building was known as St Pancras Chambers and was used as railway offices.[1][2]

hotels.name: Strand Palace Hotel
hotels.description: The Strand Palace Hotel is a large hotel on the north side of the Strand, London, England, positioned close to Covent Garden, Aldwych, Trafalgar Square and the River Thames.[1]

hotels.name: Swisstel The Howard
hotels.description: Swissôtel Hotels and Resorts is a group of hotels pitched at the higher end of the hotel market. The chain currently includes 37 properties in 17 countries. The corporate offices for Swissôtel are located in the Prioria Business Center on the property of Zurich Airport, Kloten, Switzerland,[6][7] near Zurich.[8] and the company is headed by President, Meinhard Huck.

hotels.name: The Dorchester
hotels.description: The Dorchester is a five-star luxury hotel on Park Lane and Deanery Street, London, to the east of Hyde Park. It is one of the world's most prestigious and expensive hotels.[1][2] The Dorchester opened on 18 April 1931,[3] and still retains its 1930s furnishings and ambiance despite being modernised.

hotels.name: Threadneedles Hotel
hotels.description: Threadneedles Hotel (formerly head offices of the London, City and Midland Bank headquarters) is a 5-star London hotel with 74 rooms and suites. The hotel is located opposite the Bank of England on Threadneedle Street.

hotels.name: Tower Hotel, London
hotels.description: The Tower Hotel, part of the Guoman collection, is situated on the north bank of the River Thames, on the east side of Tower Bridge, in London. It is built in a modern style considered unattractive by many, indeed it was voted the second ugliest building in London in a 2006 BBC poll.[1] However, it is reputed to offer occupants excellent views from its rooms.

hotels.name: Trafalgar Hilton
hotels.description: The Trafalgar is a hotel in London, owned by Hilton Hotels & Resorts. It is Hilton's first unbranded property.

hotels.name: Waldorf Hilton
hotels.description: The Waldorf Hotel, now known as the The Waldorf Hilton Hotel London, is a hotel based in The Aldwych, London. It has a history dating back to 1908. It was founded by William Waldorf Astor, 1st Viscount Astor, part of the Astor family.

hotels.name: Wyndham Grand Chelsea Harbour
hotels.description: Wyndham Grand London Chelsea Harbour is the only luxury 5-star all-suite hotel in London, England. Located near the boutiques of Kings Road, the hotel has 158 suites, including 4 penthouse suites with panoramic vistas.

hotels.name: YOTEL
hotels.description: YOTEL is an international, budget hotel brand, and forms part of the YO! Company. It was founded by Simon Woodroffe OBE and former company CEO Gerard Greene.[1] Whilst its rooms are slightly smaller than more traditional hotel rooms, drawing inspiration from Japanese capsule hotels, they are designed to incorporate all the usual features, from en-suite bathroom to pull-out workstation and flat screen television.[2]

hotels.name: Balmer Lawn
hotels.description: Coordinates: 50°49′N 1°34′W﻿ / ﻿50.82°N 01.57°W﻿ / 50.82; -01.57

hotels.name: Chewton Glen
hotels.description: Chewton Glen is a five star hotel and spa located on the edge of the New Forest National Park on the South Coast of England.[1]

hotels.name: Hotel Terravina
hotels.description: Hotel TerraVina is a boutique New Forest Hotel near Southampton in Hampshire, established by Gerard Basset and his wife Nina. Gerard co-founded Hotel du Vin with Robin Hutson.[1][2] The hotel has 11 bedrooms, a large restaurant, bar and terrace and a swimming pool.

hotels.name: Lainston House
hotels.description: Lainston House, an Exclusive Hotel is a 17th-century country house hotel in Winchester, Hampshire in the south of England.[1][2]

hotels.name: Queens Hotel (Southsea)
hotels.description: Queens Hotel is a luxury hotel in Southsea, Portsmouth, Hampshire. The current hotel was built in 1903[1] by the architect T.W. Cutler in the Edwardian baroque style in brown terracotta. It replaced the original Southsea House which had been built by the architect Augustus Livesay in 1861 and gutted by a fire on December 8 1891. The book England describes the hotel as a "Magnificent Edwardian hotel overlooking the Common, with ornate stone-carved balconies and countless neoclassical decorative flourishes".[1]The hotel contains 74 rooms and has two bars and a restaurant.

hotels.name: Burton Court, Eardisland
hotels.description: Eardisland, Leominster, Herefordshire, HR6 9DN, United Kingdom

hotels.name: Rhydspence Inn
hotels.description: The Rhydspence Inn is a 14th-century inn situated on the Wales-England border and within the Wye Valley overlooking the Welsh hills and Herefordshire countryside.

hotels.name: Sun Inn
hotels.description: The Sun Inn is a Grade II listed, parlour pub in Leintwardine, Herefordshire, England SY7 0LP.[1][2]

hotels.name: The Brocket Arms
hotels.description: The Brocket Arms is a 14th-century country inn in Ayot St. Lawrence, Hertfordshire. The Brocket Arms was originally the monastic quarters for the Norman church until the Reformation. It was a stop of point for pilgrims on their way to St Albans Abbey. It is said to be haunted by a priest who was tried and hanged in the building.[1] Others say it is of a monk who hanged himself at the inn.[2]

hotels.name: Brocket Hall
hotels.description: Coordinates: 51°48′04″N 0°14′46″W﻿ / ﻿51.801°N 0.246°W﻿ / 51.801; -0.246

hotels.name: Fanhams Hall
hotels.description: Fanhams Hall is an 18th-century Queen Anne House-style hotel Ware, Hertfordshire in the south east of England.[1]

hotels.name: Hanbury Manor
hotels.description: Hanbury Manor is located in Cambridge Road, Ware, Hertfordshire. Formerly a manor house and boarding school, it is now a hotel and country club.

hotels.name: Hunton Park
hotels.description: Coordinates: 51°41′35″N 0°25′30″W﻿ / ﻿51.693123°N 0.425034°W﻿ / 51.693123; -0.425034 Hunton Park is a large country house and estate in Abbots Langley, in south west Hertfordshire in the United Kingdom. It was originally called Hazelwood House when first built in the early 19th century. The original house was destroyed in 1908 and completely rebuilt. It is now a hotel.

hotels.name: Sopwell House
hotels.description: Sopwell House is a historic Georgian country house, now a luxurious 129 room hotel, country club & spa set in the southern part of St Albans, Hertfordshire, England. It gained fame as the gathering place for the England national football team before international football events, as well as welcoming club and international football teams from across the world since the nineties. Mixing country house charm with contemporary design features, the extensive facilities include a dedicated conference & banqueting centre, 2 restaurants and 2 bars, cardio and weights gym, state-of-the-art dance studio, Japanese-inspired spa which was refurbished in February 2012 and much more.

hotels.name: The Grove, Watford
hotels.description: The Grove, set in 300 acres (1.2 km2) of parkland next to the River Gade, the Grand Union Canal, and the M25 motorway near Watford, Hertfordshire, England, was originally built as a home for the Earls of Clarendon.

hotels.name: Farringford House
hotels.description: Farringford was the much loved home of Poet Laureate, Alfred Lord Tennyson, for forty years until his death in 1892. The main house dates from 1806 with gothic embellishments and extensions added from the 1830s. Of particular historical importance is the second library built by Lady Emily Tennyson in 1871 with a play room below connected by a turreted winding staircase. The grounds are laid to lawn, rose borders and informal planting. Evidence remains of Tennyson's planting schemes together with a section of the walled garden and wooden footpaths.

hotels.name: Hotel du Vin (Tunbridge Wells)
hotels.description: The Hotel du Vin & Bistro is a hotel in Crescent Road, Tunbridge Wells, Kent, England. It lies in between St Augustine's Catholic Church and Eynshym House. The hotel is part of the Hotel du Vin chain. It is located in a Grade II listed sandstone building[1] dated to 1762 and overlooks Caverley Park. The building was extended in the 1830s by Decimus Burton and contains 36 bedrooms, a billiards room and a boules court as of 2011, although 32 rooms and 1 suite were reported in 2001.[1][2] John Gielgud was a frequent visitor to the hotel.[2]

hotels.name: Larkfield Priory Hotel
hotels.description: Larkfield Priory Hotel in Larkfield, beefits from being on the A20 London Road, just 4 miles north west of Maidstone, Kent.

hotels.name: The Imperial Hotel Blackpool
hotels.description: The Imperial Hotel, formerly Puma Hotels Collection, is a 4-star hotel on the Northern Promenade of Blackpool, Lancashire, England. It was established in 1867 and is situated in a large Victorian red brick building, in what, before development, was once Claremont Park.[1] Owned by Barceló Hotels for many years, it is now operated by The Hotels Collection since 10 June 2014. The hotel features a gold and blue facade, 180 rooms, The Palm Court Restaurant and the Number 10 Bar.

hotels.name: Midland Hotel, Morecambe
hotels.description: Coordinates: 54°04′20″N 2°52′31″W﻿ / ﻿54.0721°N 2.8754°W﻿ / 54.0721; -2.8754

hotels.name: Norbreck Castle Hotel
hotels.description: Norbreck Castle Hotel is a large hotel located on Queens Promenade in the Norbreck area of Blackpool, Lancashire England on the sea front. The hotel has 480 bedrooms and 22 conference suites including the Norcalympia Conference Centre.

hotels.name: Bosworth Hall (Market Bosworth)
hotels.description: Bosworth Hall is a historic country house and Grade II* listed building in the rural town of Market Bosworth in Leicestershire, England, now known as the Bosworth Hall Hotel. It was the country seat of the Dixie family (baronets of Bosworth) for nearly three hundred years. Since the 1980s the house has had several owners and is now a hotel.

hotels.name: Grand Hotel (Leicester)
hotels.description: The Grand Hotel is a large hotel in the City centre of Leicester, England. It is now known as the Mercure Leicester City Hotel.

hotels.name: Kilworth House
hotels.description: Kilworth House is a four star country house hotel, located west of North Kilworth, Leicestershire.[1]

hotels.name: The City Rooms (Leicester)
hotels.description: The City Rooms is located in the heart of the City of Leicester in England. It has been designated by English Heritage as a grade I listed building.[1]

hotels.name: Stoke Rochford Hall
hotels.description: Stoke Rochford Hall is a large house built in scenic grounds, with a nearby golf course, next to the A1 in south Lincolnshire, England.

hotels.name: Hill Bark
hotels.description: Hill Bark is a large country house to the south of the hamlet of Frankby, Wirral, Merseyside, England. It is designated by English Heritage as a Grade II* listed building.[1] The authors of the Buildings of England series comment that it is "one of the most notable Victorian essays in half-timbered design anywhere in the country".[2]

hotels.name: Thornton Manor
hotels.description: Thornton Manor is a large house in the village of Thornton Hough, Wirral, Merseyside, England. It is designated by English Heritage as a Grade II listed building.[1] The house was first built in the middle of the 19th century and has been altered and extended in a number of phases since. From 1888 to the end of the 20th century the house was occupied by the Viscounts Leverhulme. It is now used as a conference and events centre, and a venue for weddings.

hotels.name: Bell Hotel, Thetford
hotels.description: The Bell Hotel is an AA[3] 3 star hotel in the English town of Thetford within the county of Norfolk in the United Kingdom[4] The hotel has been a grade II listed building since 3 April 1951.[2]

hotels.name: Cliftonville Hotel, Cromer
hotels.description: The Cliftonville Hotel is a AA 3 star Hotel,[2] and Grade II listed building, located in the English seaside town of Cromer in the county of Norfolk, United Kingdom.[3]

hotels.name: Dales Country House Hotel, Upper Sheringham
hotels.description: The Dales Country House Hotel is a grade II listed building which is in the English coastal village of Upper Sheringham in the county of Norfolk, United Kingdom.[3] The hotel is also an AA 4-star[4] hotel. The hotel also has 2 AA Rosettes for Food.

hotels.name: Duke's Head Hotel, King's Lynn
hotels.description: The Duke's Head Hotel is an AA[2] 4 star hotel in the English town of King's Lynn within the county of Norfolk in the United Kingdom[3] The hotel has been a grade II listed building since 1 December 1951.

hotels.name: Dunston Hall Hotel
hotels.description: Dunston Hall Hotel is a mock Elizabethan grade II listed building in the English village of Dunston, in the county of Norfolk, United Kingdom. [2] The hotel is part of the De Vere group of hotels. The hotel has an AA four star rating.[3]

hotels.name: Durdans, Mundesley
hotels.description: the Durdans Bed and Breakfast Hotel is located in the English seaside village of Mundesley in the county of Norfolk, United Kingdom.[2] The guest house is a 4-star bed and breakfast with a Silver Award from Visit Britain.

hotels.name: George Hotel, Swaffham
hotels.description: The George Hotel is a 4 star (Self assessed) hotel located in the English town of Swaffham, within the county of Norfolk, United Kingdom.[2] The hotel is a grade II listed building.

hotels.name: Golden Lion Hotel, Hunstanton
hotels.description: The Golden Lion Hotel is in the coastal English town of Hunstanton, King's Lynn and West Norfolk, Norfolk, England.[2] It is a three-star hotel and has been a Grade II listed building since 20 September 1984.

hotels.name: Griffin Hotel, Attleborough
hotels.description: The Griffin Hotel is located in the English town of Attleborough in the county of Norfolk.[2] It has been a Grade II listed building since the 21 July 1951.

hotels.name: The Lifeboat Inn, Thornham
hotels.description: The Lifeboat Inn is a public house and inn in Ship Lane, Thornham, Norfolk, England.[1] It lies near the wooded grounds of Thornham Manor.[2] The white-painted pub was originally built in the 16th century and was a smuggler's ale house.[3][4] It consists of two main buildings; the main inn having 13 double rooms, with the other being the Old Coach House which has 9 rooms.[4]

hotels.name: Links Hotel, West Runton
hotels.description: The Links Hotel is a 3 star hotel Hotel built in the Victorian era, located in the English seaside village of West Runton in the county of Norfolk, United Kingdom.[1]

hotels.name: Lynford Hall
hotels.description: Coordinates: 52°30′50″N 0°40′46″E﻿ / ﻿52.51389°N 0.67944°E﻿ / 52.51389; 0.67944

hotels.name: Maids Head Hotel
hotels.description: The Maids Head Hotel is an AA[2] 4 star hotel in the English city of Norwich within the county of Norfolk in the United Kingdom[3] The hotel has been a grade II listed building since 26 February 1954.[4]

hotels.name: Manor Hotel, Mundesley
hotels.description: The Manor Hotel is a Victorian hotel in the seaside town of Mundesley-on-sea in the county of Norfolk, United Kingdom.[1] It lies on the beachfront of Mundesley, north of Gold Park and just east of the Methodist Church. The hotel was designed by the Norwich architect John Bond Pearce[2] and was inaugurated in 1900.[3] It was the second major hotel to be established in the town, after the Hotel Continental, which was built in 1892.[3]

hotels.name: Morston Hall Hotel
hotels.description: Morston Hall is a hotel and restaurant located in the English village of Morston in North Norfolk, United Kingdom.[2] The hotel is a AA[3] 3 star hotel, and also has 3 AA Rosettes for its Food. In 1999 the restaurant was awarded a one star in the Michelin Guide, the only such award in Norfolk. The hotel's proprietor is Galton Blackiston.

hotels.name: Hotel de Paris, Cromer
hotels.description: The Hotel de Paris[2] is an AA 2 star Hotel[3] in the English seaside town of Cromer in the county of Norfolk, United Kingdom.[4] The Hotel has been a Grade II listed building since 21 January 1977.[5] A hotel or boarding house has been on the site in the early 1830s, and the name "Hotel de Paris" is recorded as early as 1845. The building was remodelled and extended to incorporate neighbouring properties in the 1890s; the architect for the alterations was George Skipper of Norwich.

hotels.name: Royal Hotel, Great Yarmouth
hotels.description: The Royal Hotel is a grade II listed building which is in the English seaside resort town of Great Yarmouth in the county of Norfolk, United Kingdom.[3]

hotels.name: Sandcliff Hotel, Cromer
hotels.description: The Sandcliff Hotel is an AA[1] 3 star hotel located on the seafront in the English town of Cromer, within the county of Norfolk, United Kingdom.[2]

hotels.name: Sea Marge Hotel, Overstrand
hotels.description: The Sea Marge Hotel is an AA 3-star[2] hotel in the English seaside village of Overstrand in the county of Norfolk.[3] The hotel also has 2 AA Rosettes for Food.

hotels.name: Sprowston Manor
hotels.description: Sprowston Manor Hotel is a AA 4 star hotel, part of which is the 19th-century Sprowston Hall. It is located on the north east suburbs, of the English city of Norwich, close to the suburb of Sprowston and village of Rackheath, within the county of Norfolk, United Kingdom.[1]

hotels.name: Star Hotel, Great Yarmouth
hotels.description: The Star Hotel is a 3 star (self assessed) hotel in the English town of Great Yarmouth within the county of Norfolk in the United Kingdom.[2] The hotel has been a grade II listed building since February 26, 1998.[3]

hotels.name: The Red Lion Hotel, Cromer
hotels.description: The Red Lion Hotel [1]is a AA 4 star Hotel[2] located in the English seaside town of Cromer in the county of Norfolk, United Kingdom.[3]

hotels.name: Talbot Hotel
hotels.description: The Talbot Hotel or Talbot Inn is an Elizabethan hotel in Oundle, Northamptonshire, England.

hotels.name: Clennell Hall
hotels.description: Coordinates: 55°21′30″N 2°06′49″W﻿ / ﻿55.35831°N 2.11354°W﻿ / 55.35831; -2.11354

hotels.name: Embleton Hall
hotels.description: Coordinates: 55°18′18″N 1°47′49″W﻿ / ﻿55.305°N 1.797°W﻿ / 55.305; -1.797

hotels.name: Langley Castle Hotel
hotels.description: Coordinates: 54°57′22″N 2°15′32″W﻿ / ﻿54.956°N 2.259°W﻿ / 54.956; -2.259

hotels.name: Marshall Meadows Country House Hotel
hotels.description: Marshall Meadows Country House Hotel is a Georgian mansion and the most northern hotel in England, located north of Berwick-upon-Tweed, Northumberland, in northeastern England. It is set in 15 acres of grounds only 275 metres from the border.[1][2]

hotels.name: Matfen Hall Hotel
hotels.description: Matfen Hall is a 19th-century country mansion in Matfen, Northumberland, England, the seat of the Blackett baronets and now also a hotel and country golf club. It is a Grade II* listed building.

hotels.name: Otterburn Hall Hotel
hotels.description: Otterburn Hall is a AA four-star fortified English country house and estate, now used as a hotel, in Otterburn, Northumberland. It is situated in 500 acres (200 ha) of deer park and woodland in the Northumberland National Park, northeastern England. The building was constructed in 1870 for Lord James Douglas, the land given to him as recompense for the death of Lord James Douglas, who fought at the Battle of Otterburn, and was killed near Otterburn Tower (originally a castle), itself founded in 1086, and rebuilt in 1830. Both Otterburn Hall and Otterburn Castle have been seats of landed gentry.[1] 15 August 2012 - Otterburn Hall Hotel Closes without notice.

hotels.name: Schooner Hotel
hotels.description: The Schooner Hotel & Bar is a Grade II listed 17th century coaching inn and hotel located at 8 Northumberland Street in the coastal village of Alnmouth, Northumberland, England.[1] The hotel lies on the main High Street and is recognizable by its whitewashed walls and black painted shutters.[2][3]The 32-room hotel is amongst the best known hotels in northeastern England and in the 19th century had a considerable reputation with a clientele of people such as Charles Dickens, John Wesley, Basil Rathbone, and King George III of England.[4]

hotels.name: The White Swan Hotel, Alnwick
hotels.description: The White Swan Hotel is a hotel in the middle of the historic market town of Alnwick, Northumberland, England. The hotel is a 300-year-old coaching inn and is a Grade II listed building. Its most distinctive feature is the Olympic Suite, a large room furnished with interior decorations from the RMS Olympic that are substantially identical to those aboard her sister ship, the RMS Titanic.

hotels.name: Clifton Hotel (England)
hotels.description: Coordinates: 54°17′24″N 0°24′18″W﻿ / ﻿54.290°N 0.405°W﻿ / 54.290; -0.405 The Clifton Hotel is a small, late Victorian hotel in Scarborough, North Yorkshire, England. The hotel stands on the North Bay cliff tops and was home to soldiers on home duty during both World War I and World War II. The location of the building offers commanding views of the North Sea.

hotels.name: Crown Spa Hotel
hotels.description: The Crown Spa Hotel (formerly the Crown Hotel) is a large hotel in Scarborough, North Yorkshire, England. This is Scarborough's first purpose-built hotel, completed in May 1844 and opened for business on 10 June 1845.[1] It overlooks the town's South Bay and is privately owned by a local family.

hotels.name: Grand Hotel (Scarborough)
hotels.description: The Grand Hotel is a large hotel in Scarborough, England, overlooking the town's South Bay. It is now a Grade II* listed building that is owned by Britannia Hotels, and has undergone a £7 million refurbishment.[1]

hotels.name: Hazlewood Castle
hotels.description: Hazlewood Castle is a country residence, now a hotel, situated in North Yorkshire, England by the A1 and A64 between Aberford and Tadcaster.

hotels.name: Holbeck Hall Hotel
hotels.description: The Holbeck Hall Hotel was a clifftop hotel in Scarborough, North Yorkshire, England, owned by English Rose Hotels. The hotel had scenic views of the sea and surrounding area. It was built in 1879 by George Alderson Smith as a private residence, and was later converted to a hotel.[1] On 3 June 1993, a landslide began beneath the hotel. This increased, and finally on 5 June 1993, a day of heavy rain, parts of the building dramatically fell into the sea, making news around the world. The remainder of the building had to be demolished by contractors.

hotels.name: Hotel Majestic (Harrogate)
hotels.description: The Majestic Hotel in Harrogate, North Yorkshire, England, is a historic hotel and is a listed building operating by The Hotel Collection.

hotels.name: Middlethorpe Hall
hotels.description: Middlethorpe Hall is a 17th-century country house standing in 20 acres of grounds in Middlethorpe, York, North Yorkshire, England. It is currently used as an hotel.[1]

hotels.name: Old Swan Hotel
hotels.description: The Old Swan Hotel in Harrogate, North Yorkshire, England, is part of the Classic Lodges group.

hotels.name: Swinton Park
hotels.description: Swinton Park, the seat of the Danby family and (from 1882) of the Cunliffe-Lister family is an English country house in Swinton near Masham, North Yorkshire, England. It is set in 200 acres (0.81 km2) of parkland, lakes and gardens. Currently operating as a 30-bedroom hotel, it is surrounded by the family estate in which guests have access to rivers, reservoirs, moorland, dales, and beautiful countryside bordering the Yorkshire Dales National Park.

hotels.name: Bear Hotel
hotels.description: The Bear Hotel is a hotel in Woodstock, Oxfordshire, located opposite The Oxfordshire Museum, not far from Blenheim Palace. It is one of England's original 13th century coaching inns and has stone walls, oak beams, open fireplaces and an ivy facade. The hotel has 53 bedrooms and its restaurant has 2 A.A. Rosettes and 2 RAC Dining Awards.[1] It is run by MacDonald Hotels and Resorts. Notable guests include Richard Burton and Elizabeth Taylor who stayed at the hotel on many occasions in the Marlboro suite.[2][3]

hotels.name: French Horn, Sonning Eye
hotels.description: The French Horn at Sonning is a luxury hotel and restaurant on the banks of the River Thames next to the Sonning Backwater Bridges (on the B478 road), at Sonning Eye, Oxfordshire, England.[1][2]

hotels.name: Holt Hotel
hotels.description: The Holt Hotel is an historic hotel near Steeple Aston, Oxfordshire, England. It is on the corner of the crossroads between the A4260 Oxford Road and the B4030, about 1 mile (1.6 km) southwest of Steeple Aston opposite a fuel station. It was founded in 1475 as a coaching inn with six rooms and now has 86 rooms.[1] Its restaurant has been awarded a AA Rosette for quality cuisine.[1]

hotels.name: Le Manoir aux Quat' Saisons
